1.title: Below the tropopause, the ICAO Standard Atmosphere (ISA) assumes?

variants.a: A mean sea level pressure of 1013.25mb together with a mean sea level temperature of 15°C, decreasing by 1.98°C per 1000ft up to 36,090ft.
variants.b: A mean sea level pressure of 1013.25mb together with a mean sea level temperature of 15°C, decreasing at a rate of 2°C per 1000 ft until it reaches -65.6°C at 36,090ft.
variants.c: A surface pressure of 1013.25mb together with a sea level temperature of 15°C, decreasing at the rate of 1.98°C per 1000ft until it reaches absolute zero.
variants.d: A mean sea level pressure of 1225g/m-3 together with a mean sea level temperature of 15°C, decreasing at a rate of 2°C per 1000ft up to 36,090ft,

2.title: Where is most of the water vapour in the atmosphere contained?

variants.d: Stratopause.

3.title: What are the proportions of gases in the atmosphere?

variants.d: Nitrogen 78%, Oxygen 21%, Hydrogen 1%.

4.title: The layer closest to the earth's surface where the majority of weather is found is called?

variants.d: Mesosphere.

5.title: The temperature at 2000ft above mean sea level is forecast to be 5°C; compared to the ICAO Standard Atmosphere (ISA) this is:

variants.d: IAS -6 PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      3 / 28

6.title: What is the name of the instrument which gives a continuous printed reading and record of the atmospheric pressure?

variants.d: Anemograph

variants.a: Decreases at a decreasing rate as height increases.
variants.b: Decreases at an increasing rate as height increases.
variants.c: Decreases at a constant rate as height increases.
variants.d: Decreases at a constant rate up to the Tropopause and then remains constant.

8.title: What is the significance of tightly spaced isobars?

variants.a: A large pressure gradient and strong winds.
variants.b: A weak pressure gradient and light winds.
variants.c: A weak pressure gradient and strong winds.
variants.d: A large pressure gradient and light winds.

9.title: A line drawn on a chart joining places having the same barometric pressure at the same level and at the same time is?

variants.d: A contour.

10.title: Compared to ISA, what does warm air do to the distance represented by a 1 hpa change in pressure?

variants.d: Impossible to determine.

11.title: What is the density at sea level in the International Standard Atmosphere?

12.title: Density at the surface will be low when:

variants.a: Pressure is low and temperature is high.
variants.b: Pressure is high and temperature is high.
variants.c: Pressure is high and temperature is low.
variants.d: Pressure is low and temperature is low. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      4 / 28

variants.c: Temperature and pressure increase and density decreases.
variants.d: Temperature decreases and pressure density increases.

variants.c: Weight of air per unit area.
variants.d: Volume divided by mass.

15.title: Under what conditions would density be the least at any given place?

variants.a: High altitude, high temperature and high humidity.
variants.b: Low altitude, high temperature and high humidity.
variants.c: High altitude, high temperature and low humidity.
variants.d: Low altitude, low temperature and low humidity.

16.title: Consider the following statements about air density and select the one which is correct?

variants.a: At any given surface temperature the air density will be greater in anticyclonic conditions than it will be when the mean sea level pressure is lower.
variants.b: Because air density increases with a decrease of temperature, air density must increase with increase of height in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA).
variants.c: Air density increases with an increase of relative humidity.
variants.d: The effect of change of temperature on the air density is much greater than the effect of change of atmospheric pressure.

17.title: The diurnal variation of temperature is:

variants.a: Reduced anywhere by the presence of cloud.
variants.b: Greater over the sea than overland.
variants.c: Less over desert areas than over temperate grassland.
variants.d: Increased anywhere as wind speed increases.

18.title: If temperature remains constant with an increase in altitude there is:

variants.d: Decreased lapse rate.

19.title: A trough of low pressure at the surface is generally associated with:

variants.a: Convergence causing increased cloud and precipitation.
variants.b: Divergence causing increased cloud and precipitation.
variants.c: Subsidence causing increased cloud and precipitation.
variants.d: Subsidence causing decreased cloud and precipitation. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      5 / 28

20.title: During the winter months, which of the following weather conditions would most likely be produced by an anticyclone?

variants.a: General subsidence with adiabatic warming, clear skies, and an inversion.
variants.b: Subsidence due to surface cooling creating extensive cloud.
variants.c: During the day, the surface warming would create an unstable atmosphere with extensive convective cloud.
variants.d: During the night, as the land cools, there would be an increase in the vertical cloud development.

21.title: Diurnal variation of the surface temperature will:

variants.b: Be unaffected by a change of wind speed.
variants.d: Be at a minimum in calm conditions.

22.title: Cloud cover will reduce surface diurnal variation of temperature because:

variants.a: Incoming solar radiation is reflected back to space and terrestrial radiation is re-radiated from the cloud back to the surface layer.
variants.b: Incoming solar radiation is reflected back to space and outgoing terrestrial radiation is reflected back to earth.
variants.c: Incoming solar radiation is re-radiated back to space and atmospheric heating by convection will stop at the level of the cloud layer.
variants.d: The cloud stops the sun's rays getting through to the earth and also reduces outgoing conduction

23.title: An area of indeterminate pressure between two lows and two highs is called: Every physical process of weather is accompanied by, or is the result of, a

variants.d: A saddle.

24.title: The method by which energy is transferred from one body to another with which it is in contact is called:

variants.d: Latent heat.

25.title: The sun gives out_____amounts of energy with_____wavelengths.The earth gives out relatively_____amounts of energy with relatively_____wavelengths:

variants.d: Large / large / small / large. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      6 / 28

variants.a: There is an increase of temperature as height increases.
variants.b: There is no horizontal gradient of temperature.
variants.c: There is no change of temperature with height.
variants.d: There is a decrease of temperature as height Increases.

27.title: Which of the statements below best describes a COL?

variants.a: An area of widely spaced isobars between two highs and two lows.
variants.b: An area between two highs where the isobars are very close together.
variants.d: An extension of low pressure.

28.title: A ridge of high pressure is generally associated with:

variants.a: Subsidence of air, then divergence at the surface causing clear skies and poor visibility.
variants.b: Convergence at the surface causing increased cloud and precipitation.
variants.c: Divergence at the surface causing an improvement in the surface visibility.
variants.d: Subsidence then divergence at the surface causing cloud to break up and more precipitation

29.title: When flying towards a depression at a constant indicated altitude, the true altitude will be:

variants.d: Lower than indicated at first then the same as indicated later.

30.title: When an altimeter sub scale is set to the aerodrome OFE, the altimeter reads:

variants.a: Zero at the aerodrome reference point.
variants.b: The elevation of the aerodrome at the aerodrome reference point.
variants.c: The pressure altitude at the aerodrome reference point.
variants.d: The appropriate altitude of the aircraft.

variants.a: The vertical distance above the pressure level set in the sub scale.
variants.b: With 1013 set,  the altitude above MSL.
variants.c: With airfield QNH set, the height above the airfield datum.
variants.d: The correct flight level with regional QFE set.

32.title: An aircraft flies at a constant indicated altitude from airfield A (QNH 1009mb) to airfield B (QNH 1019mb). If the subscale is not reset from 1009, what would be expected when over airfield B:

variants.a: Indicated altitude to be less than actual altitude.
variants.b: Indicated altitude to be the same as actual altitude.
variants.c: Indicated altitude to be more than actual altitude.
variants.d: Indicated altitude may be greater or less depending on the airfield elevation. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      7 / 28

33.title: The name given to the lowest forecast mean sea level pressure in an area is:

variants.d: QNE.

34.title: An aircraft flies from aerodrome "A", where QNH is given as 1020mb, to aerodrome "B", where the QNH is given as 999mb. Aerodrome "A" is 800ft above mean sea level and aerodrome "B" is 500ft above mean sea level. If the altimeter sub scale is not changed from 1020, what is the altimeter indication on landing?   (ASSUME 1mb = 30ft)

35.title: You experience a constant drift to the right when flying over Europe at a constant indicated altitude. If the altimeter subscale is not updated, this will result in?

variants.a: Flying at a progressively lower true altitude.
variants.b: Flying at a progressively higher true altitude.
variants.c: Flying at a progressively lower indicated altitude.
variants.d: Flying at a progressively higher indicated altitude.

36.title: You are flying at a constant indicated altitude with the QNH of 1015 set within the subscale and you notice the outside air temperature has been falling constantly. What can you expect to have happened to your true altitude?

variants.d: Increased then decreased.

37.title: The instrument used for measuring the humidity of air is a:

variants.d: Hygroscope.

38.title: When condensation takes place, the higher the temperature the_____the amount of latent heat_____:

variants.d: Lesser / absorbed. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      8 / 28

39.title: Wet bulb temperature would normally be lower than dry bulb temperature because:

variants.a: Evaporation causes cooling on the wet bulb thermometer.
variants.b: Condensation causes a release of latent heat.
variants.c: Latent heat is absorbed by the bulb thermometer.
variants.d: Of condensation on the muslin wick of the bulb.

40.title: The process of change of state from a gas to a liquid is known as:

variants.a: Condensation in which latent heat is released.
variants.b: Evaporation in which latent heat is absorbed.
variants.c: Evaporation in which latent heat is released.
variants.d: Condensation in which latent heat is absorbed.

41.title: A change of state directly from a solid to a vapour or vice versa is:

variants.d: Evaporation.

42.title: During a night with a clear sky, surface temperature will_____Relative Humidity will_____and Dewpoint will_____.

variants.d: Fall / Fall / Remain the same.

43.title: Which of the processes listed below can cause air to become saturated?

variants.d: Heating.

44.title: When receiving circuit joining information prior to an approach at a destination airfield, the pilot of a light aircraft is warned of the presence of low level windshear. The pilot should?

variants.a: Delay the approach or even consider diverting.
variants.b: Use a higher than normal approach speed to counteract any loss of headwind component
variants.c: Consider the possibility of a missed approach.
variants.d: Land using the normal landing technique but monitor speed carefully.

45.title: Given an atmospheric situation where the relative humidity is 60% and the ELR is less than the DALR, if air is forced to rise it will be:

variants.a: Stable and will tend to regain its former position.
variants.b: Unstable and will carry on rising.
variants.c: Stable and will carry on rising.
variants.d: Unstable and will tend to regain its former position. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      9 / 28

46.title: The pilot of an aircraft which is approaching a mountain from the downwind or leeward side, a few hundred feet above ridge level, observes venticular clouds. Which of the following conditions would the pilot expect to encounter as the flight continues?

variants.a: Strong down-draughts immediately before the ridge of the mountain is reached, with strong up-draughts after passing the ridge to the windward side.
variants.b: Strong katabatic currents at the top of the ridge.
variants.c: Strong katabatic down-draughts and turbulence after passing over the ridge.
variants.d: Strong up-draughts before the ridge is passed and strong down-draughts after the ridge is passed.

47.title: The actual change of temperature with height is known as...

variants.d: The tephigram.

48.title: Which of the following is true about the lowest level windshear?

variants.a: It may be experienced 15 to 20 miles ahead of a fast moving thunderstorm.
variants.b: It is rare where there is a strong inversion level close to the surface.
variants.c: It is only found under the core of the anvil of a thunderstorm.
variants.d: It is only ever found on the fringes of a microburst.

49.title: An aircraft is flying in the vicinity of a range of hills, lying north-south, across which a wind is blowing from the west to east. Which of the following situations might cause the aircraft to encounter dangerous downdraughts?

variants.a: When flying west towards the hills from the east.
variants.b: When flying east towards the hills from the west.
variants.c: When flying north towards the hill from the south.
variants.d: When flying south towards the hill from the north.

50.title: Which of the following is true about the lowest level windshear?

variants.a: It may be experienced 15 to 20 miles ahead of a fast moving thunderstorm.
variants.b: It is rare where there is a strong inversion level close to the surface.
variants.c: It is only found under the core of the anvil of a thunderstorm.
variants.d: It is only ever found on the fringes of a microburst.

51.title: In a mountain wave situation, the worst of the turbulence is most likely to be found when flying:

variants.a: In or just below the roll cloud.
variants.b: At about mid-height between the lenticular and roll cloud.
variants.d: In the lenticular cloud. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      10 / 28

52.title: Which of the following characterises unstable air?

variants.a: Cumulus cloud with showers and generally good visibility outside of the showers.
variants.b: Layered cloud with showers and generally poor visibility.
variants.c: Layered cloud with poor visibility and intermittent drizzle.
variants.d: Cumulus cloud with continuous precipitation and moderate visibility.

53.title: A light aircraft flying at low level near a mountain range across which a strong wind is blowing may expect: 1. Severe turbulence below or within any rotor zone. 2. Down-draughts which may exceed the climb rate of the aircraft. 3. A greater than normal risk of icing in the cloud over the crest mountain. 4. Lenticular cloud

variants.d: Only 1, 2 and 4 are correct

54.title: One or more coloured rings around the sun or moon may indicate the presence of which type of cloud?

variants.d: Cirrocumulus.

55.title: Given a surface temperature of+21°C and a dew point of +7°C, at approximately what height will the cloud base of a cumulus cloud be?

56.title: Hail is most likely to fall from which type of cloud?

variants.d: AS.

57.title: From the list below, select the Low, Medium and High clouds in ascending order.

variants.d: Cirrus, Cumulonimbus, Stratus. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      11 / 28

58.title: The use of the suffix "nimbus" or the prefix "nimbo" means?

variants.d: Dark and threatening.

59.title: Precipitation produced by stratus is normally?

variants.d: Light showers.

60.title: Unstable air is forced to rise up the side of a mountain. What weather might you expect to see on the windward slopes?

variants.c: None, as the air will subside and warm adiabatically after passing over the summit.
variants.d: Cap clouds with possible altocumulus lenticularis.

61.title: The conditions which must exist to allow thunderstorms to develop are:

variants.a: A plentiful supply of moisture and a steep lapse rate through a large vertical extent, together with a trigger action.
variants.b: A trigger action, a plentiful supply of moisture and a very stable atmosphere.
variants.c: A steep lapse rate, a stable atmosphere through a large vertical extent, and a plentiful supply of moisture.
variants.d: A steep lapse rate through a large vertical extent, a low relative humidity and a trigger action.

62.title: Which of the following combinations of weather-producing variables would be most likely to result in cumuliform clouds, good visibility, showery rain, and possible clear type icing in clouds?

variants.a: Unstable moist air and orographic lifting.
variants.b: Stable, moist air and orographic lifting.
variants.c: Unstable moist air and no lifting mechanism.
variants.d: Stable, dry air and orographic lifting.

63.title: Turbulence, windshear, icing, lightning and heavy precipitation are associated with cumulonimbus clouds. Which of the following statements is true?

variants.a: All of the hazards can be avoided by not flying in or in the vicinity of the cloud.
variants.b: The most hazardous condition is lightning.
variants.c: Heavy precipitation may be experienced outside the cloud, but turbulence and icing are confined to inside the cloud.
variants.d: All of the hazards may be encountered within or in the viciniity of the cloud. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      12 / 28

64.title: During the_____stage of a thunderstorm ceil, the cloud contains_____. Complete the above statement choosing one of the following combinations of words:

variants.a: Mature / up currents and down currents.
variants.c: Dissipating / up currents and down currents.
variants.d: Initial / down currents only.

65.title: What stage of a thunderstorm is characterised predominantly by downdraughts?

variants.d: Cumulus stage.

66.title: For cumulonimbus clouds to develop, there needs to exist?

variants.a: A deep layer of very unstable moist air.
variants.b: A shallow layer of very unstable moist air.
variants.c: A deep layer of very unstable moist air with a shallow lapse rate.
variants.d: A shallow layer of very unstable air with a steep lapse rate.

67.title: What stage of a thunderstorm is characterised by updraughts only?

variants.d: End stage.

68.title: Which of the following conditions are most likely to produce thunderstorms?

variants.a: A high moisture content with a steep lapse rate.
variants.b: A high moisture content with a shallow lapse rate.
variants.c: A low moisture content with a steep lapse rate.
variants.d: A low moisture content with a shallow lapse rate.

69.title: Hazards to aircraft caused by the presence of cumulonimbus or thunderstorm cloud may be experienced:

variants.a: When the aircraft is within 10 nm of the cloud.
variants.b: Only when the aircraft is within the cloud.
variants.c: Only when the aircraft is within or underneath the cloud.
variants.d: When the aircraft is within 5 nm of the cloud.

70.title: Hazards of the mature stage of a thunderstorm cell include lightning, turbulence and:

variants.d: Windshear, hail and fog.. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      13 / 28

71.title: The wind at 2000ft over an aerodrome was reported at 330/15kt. Using the rule of thumb, what might you expect the surface wind to be?

72.title: Corilolis force in the Northern Hemisphere will cause moving air to be apparently deflected to:

variants.a: The right and cause the geostrophic wind to blow parallel to the isobars at about 2000ft agl.
variants.b: The left and cause the wind to blow parallel to the isobars at about 2000ft agl.
variants.c: The left and cause the wind to blow slightly across the isobars at about 2000ft agl.
variants.d: The right and cause the wind to blow slightly across the isobars at about 2000ft agl.

73.title: Winds that blow around an anticyclone (high pressure system) at lower levels in the Northern Hemisphere are represented on a low level chart as blowing in:

variants.b: A clockwise direction if it is warm air and anticlockwise if it is cold air.
variants.d: A cyclonic direction.

74.title: Low level winds in the northern hemisphere that blow around a depression are drawn on surface weather charts in?

variants.d: Either clockwise or anticlockwise depending on whether the depression is cyclonic or anticyclonic

75.title: The formation of advection fog is often caused by?

variants.a: A warm moist air mass under the influence of a moderate wind being cooled to below its dew point by flowing over a much colder surface.
variants.b: A cold moist air mass under the influence of a moderate wind being warmed to below its dew point by flowing over a much warmer surface.
variants.c: A warm moist air mass under the influence of a very light wind being cooled to below its dew point by flowing over a much colder surface.
variants.d: A warm moist air mass under the influence of a strong wind on a clear cloudless night.

76.title: A low level mist layer significantly reduces forward visibility when flying at about 2000ft. To improve your forward visiility you should?

variants.c: Fly just on top of the mist layer.
variants.d: Turn on your landing lights and strobe lights. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      14 / 28

77.title: Which of the following conditions is most favourable to the formation of radiation fog?

variants.a: High relative humidity, light winds and a clear sky.
variants.b: High relative humidity, moderate wind and a cloudy sky.
variants.c: Low relative humidity, light winds and a clear sky.
variants.d: High relative humidity, light winds and a cloudy sky.

78.title: Over an inland airfield radiation fog is reported in the morning. As the wind speed increases to 10 kt what would you expect:

variants.a: The fog to lift and form low stratus.
variants.d: An increase in mixing, allowing more fog to develop.

79.title: What are the characteristics of the passage of a cold front?

variants.a: A dew point fall, a temperature fall, and the wind veering.
variants.b: A dew point rise, a temperature fall and wind backing.
variants.c: Dew point rise, a temperature fall and the wind veering.
variants.d: Steady dew point and temperature but a sharp backing in the wind.

80.title: What is the general speed of the warm front?

variants.a: Approximately 2/3 of the speed of the cold front.
variants.b: Approximately 1/3 of the speed of the cold front.
variants.c: Approximately 1/2 the speed of the cold front
variants.d: The same speed as the cold front.

81.title: If a cloudy, granular type of ice is seen to collect and protrude forward from the leading edge of the aerofoil, what type of ice would it most likely be?

variants.d: Hoar frost.

82.title: What will normally happen to the surface wind direction following the passage of a warm front?

variants.d: Veer then back.

83.title: The extent of rainfall ahead of a typical warm front may be up to a distance of:

variants.a: 200 miles ahead of the surface position of the warm front
variants.b: 50 miles ahead of the surface position of the warm front.
variants.c: 500 miles ahead of the surface position of the warm front
variants.d: 2 miles ahead of the surface position of the warm front. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      15 / 28

84.title: Ice accretion in a piston engine induction system is produced by:

variants.a: Low power settings, high humidity and warm air.
variants.b: High power settings, moderate humidity and cold air.
variants.c: Low power settings, low humidity and warm air.
variants.d: High power settings, high humidity and warm air.

85.title: Which of the following frontal systems is more likely to produce thunderstorm activity?

variants.d: A quasi-stationary front.

86.title: Clear ice forms as a result of:

variants.a: Large supercooled water droplets spreading as they freeze.
variants.b: Ice pellets splattering on the aircraft.
variants.c: Small supercooled water droplets splashing over the aircraft.
variants.d: Water vapour freezing to the aircraft.

87.title: What would be the change in weather following the passage of a typical warm front:

variants.a: Pressure falls, 8 oktas of cloud with a lowering base and poor visibility.
variants.b: Pressure increases steadily, no more than 4 oktas of cloud, and good visibility.
variants.c: Pressure stops falling, 4 oktas of cloud with a very low base and rapidly improving visibility.
variants.d: Pressure falls, 8 oktas of cloud with a lowering base and improving visibility.

88.title: What is the main reason water can exist in a liquid state even though the temperature is sub zero?

variants.c: Water takes a long time to cool to below zero degrees.
variants.d: Water is hygroscopic.

89.title: You are flying above the freezing level in the cold air just ahead of a warm front. If rain were to fall in this area, what kind of icing might you expect?

variants.d: Hoar frost. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      16 / 28

90.title: Which of the following correctly decodes the METAR shown below? METAR EGKL 130350Z 32005KT 0400N DZ BCFG VV002

variants.a: Observed on the 13th day of the month at 0350Z, surface wind 320°True, 05kt, minimum visibility 400 metres to the north, moderate drizzle, with fog patches and a vertical visibility of 200ft.
variants.b: Reported on the 13th day of the month at 0350Z, surface wind 320°Magnetic, 05kt, minimum visibility 400 metres to the north, moderate drizzle, with fog patches and a vertical visibility of 200ft.
variants.c: Valid on the 13th day of the month between 0300 and 1500Z, surface wind 320°T/05kt, minimum visibility 400 metres, drizzle, with fog patches and a vertical visibility of 200 metres.
variants.d: Valid between 1300Z and 1350Z, surface wind 320°T/05kt, minimum visibility 400 metres to the north, moderate drizzle, and a vertical visibility of 200ft.

91.title: When a TREND is included at the end of an aviation METAR, the trend is a forecast valid for:

variants.a: 2 hours after the time of observation.
variants.b: 1 hour after the time of observation.
variants.d: 1 hour after it was issued.

92.title: The visibility group R20/0050 in a METAR means:

variants.a: As measured by runway measuring equipment for runway 20, a current runway visibility of 50 metres.
variants.b: For runway 20, a current visibility of 500 metres measured by runway visual range equipment
variants.c: The runway visibility reported is 50 metres as measured by the runway visual range equipment within the last 20 minutes.
variants.d: On runway 20, the current visibility is less than 5000 metres.

93.title: The code: "BECMG FM 1100 -RASH" in a METAR means:

variants.a: Becoming, from 1100 UTC, slight rain showers.
variants.b: From 1100 UTC, cessation of the rain showers.
variants.d: Becoming, from 1100 UTC to 0000 UTC, slight rain showers.

94.title: A temperature group of 28/24 in a METAR means that:

variants.a: The temperature is 28°C and the dew point is 24°C.
variants.b: The temperature is 28°C at the time of the reporting, but is expected to become 24°C by the end of the TREND report.
variants.c: The dry bulb temperautre is 28°C and the wet bulb temperature is 24°C.
variants.d: The dew point is 28°C and the temperature is 24°C. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      17 / 28

95.title: In the METAR shown below, the cloud base has been omitted. At what height might you expect the cloud base to be if cumulus cloud was present? 28005KT9999 SCT??? 12/05 Q1020 NOSIG

variants.d: SCT280.

96.title: Providing the minimum sector altitude is not a determining factor, CAVOK in a TAF or METAR:

variants.a: Means visibility 10km or more, and no cloud below 5000ft.
variants.b: Means visibility 10km or more, and few cloud below 5000ft.
variants.c: Means visibility 10nm or more, and no cloud below 5000ft.
variants.d: Means visibility 10nm or more, and no scattered cloud below 5000ft.

97.title: Which of the following correctly decodes a TAF that reads: LYBE 161100Z 1612/1712 VRB08KT9999 SCT025?

variants.a: Valid from 1200 Hr on the 16 of the month to 1200 Hr on the 17 of the month; surface wind will be variable in direction at 8kt with a visibility of 10km or more; 3to4 oktas of cloud with a base of 2500ft above the aerodrome.
variants.b: Valid from 1612 to 1712 UTC; surface wind variable at 8kt; visibility 10nm or more; with a cloud base of 2500ft above mean sea level.
variants.c: Observed at 1611UTC; the surface wind was variable in direction and speed; averaging 8kt: with a visibility of 10km or more, and a cloud base of 2500ft above aerodrome level.
variants.d: Observed at 1612 UTC; the surface wind was variable in direction and speed; with a visibility of 10km, and a cloud base of 2500ft above ground level.

98.title: BECMG 1621/1701 BKN030 in a TAF means:

variants.c: Becoming from 1621 UTC 5-7 oktas of cloud at 3000 ft agl.
variants.d: Becoming from 1621 UTC 3-4 oktas of cloud at 300 ft agl

variants.a: For a single fixed time only.
variants.d: 30 minutes.

variants.a: Moderate to severe icing and turbulence.

variants.d: Severe icing and turbulence and hail.

variants.d: Turbulence at 42,000 ft west of 4 degrees west and moving at 30 knots.

111.title: In an AIRMET when are strong wind warnings forecast?

variants.a: When the wind is expected to exceed 20kt.
variants.b: When the wind is expected to exceed 10kt.
variants.c: When the wind is expected to exceed 15kt
variants.d: When the maximum wind is expected to exceed 25kt.

2 times a day.

variants.b: Air to ground radio transmissions on HF and VHF.

124.title: What weather phenomena is associated with a temperature inversion?

variants.d: Thunderstorms inside air masses.

125.title: The most frequent type of ground or surface-based temperature inversion is that which is produced by

variants.a: Terrestrial radiation on a clear, relatively still night.
variants.b: The movement of colder air under warm air, or the movement of warm air over cold air.
variants.c: Warm air being lifted rapidly aloft in the vicinity of mountainous terrain.

126.title: The amount of water vapor which air can hold depends on the

variants.c: Dewpoint. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      22 / 28

128.title: What are the characteristics of an unstable air mass?

129.title: What types clouds usually accompany the passage of a warm front?

variants.d: CC, SC, ST, NS.

130.title: Which weather conditions should be expected beneath a low-level temperature inversion layer when the relative humidity is high?

variants.a: Light windshear, poor visibility, haze, and light rain.
variants.b: Smooth air, poor visibility, fog, haze, or low clouds.
variants.c: Turbulent air, poor visibility, fog, low stratus type clouds, and showery precipitation

variants.d: CU.

136.title: When may hazardous windshear be expected?

variants.a: In areas of low-level temperature inversion, frontal zones, and clear air turbulence.
variants.b: Following frontal passage when stratocumulus clouds form indicating mechanical mixing.
variants.c: When stable air crosses a mountain barrier where it tends to flow in layers forming lenticular clouds.

138.title: There is thunderstorm activity in the vicinity of an airport at which you plan to land, which hazardous atmospheric phenomenon might be expected on the landing approach?

variants.a: At all altitudes, in all directions.

140.title: Why is frost considered hazardous to flight?

variants.a: Frost spoils the smooth flow of air over the wings, thereby decreasing lifting capability.
variants.b: Frost slows the airflow over the airfoils, thereby increasing control effectiveness.
variants.c: Frost changes the basic aerodynamic shape of the airfoils, thereby increasing lift. PPL (A) – MeteorologyLatest information about the exam can be found atwww.cad.gov.rs/osoblje.php      24 / 28

141.title: In which environment is aircraft structural ice most likely to have the highest accumulation rate?

variants.c: Cumulus clouds with below freezing temperatures.
